Team soda
My advice:  Get a carbonater.  It adds carbonation to water in an incredibly cost effective manner.  For flavor, add just a little bit of PURE grape juices (CHECK THE INGREDIENTS.  Not all juice is really juice!) Lemon and lime juice concentrate work too, as do whole limes or lemons that have been sliced in half.  This way you aren't getting any "natural flavors", "flavors", zero sugar substitutes (even the relatively benign Stevia is icky if you use too much), preservatives, addictive substances (aspartame, sucrose, sucralate, sucr-whateter), or refined/concentrated sugars (fructose, glucose, etc.)  When I quit diet cola, it took me over a month before the headaches stop, and I continue to have cravings to this day.  If that's not a sign of addiction, I don't know what is.  I felt like couldn't sleep or work without soda.  It was not healthy for my mind or body.  For anyone who thinks they aren't addicted (and this goes for ANY  potential addiction):  Try to quit and see what symptoms you get.
He infact relapsed and is still addicted

My question is why go diet, when the sweeteners in diet are ironically less healthy. They have more kcal and linger in the body way longer. Why not make your own natural cola?  Believe it or not, there are recipes to where naking your own cola syrup are out there Mat and I do recommend it. You make it like a simple syrup with ~2 parts cane sugar to every one part water. Meanwhile the ingredients are things like Lemon, Orange, Lime, Star Anise, Cardamom, etc. Even add in Vanilla bean, Cinnamon or Cherries for whichever flavor you want. Sure it has more calories, but those natural sugars are easier to burn in the body.

I, who am now type 2, had to cut out my long standing soda addiction and find other things like Sparkling Water and such to supply my needs. Diet has always been a dirty word for me, because I was not born with the gene that allows for people to like the taste of Aspartame. 08:35 The moment they said No.2 tasted like cough syrup, I knew it was the glass bottle coke. Coke was originally created as a form of medicine back in the days, and thus, it wouldn't taste very good - unless you happen to be one of the ones that like that sort of thing. 05:01 From the "This one is slightly sweeter" I could accurately tell that the middle one was bottled Diet Coke, the left (right for them) was can, and the "slightly sweeter" was the Dispenser Diet Coke. Dispenser soda is a mixture between carbonated water and soda syrup, syrup has a more sweeter taste to it, especially if the mixing isn't as watered out as I am used to. Bottled coke fizzes a lot, so that middle glass being the bottled coke was a no brainer. Then that only left the canned coke.

Generic/store brands are the same as big brands, similar to the big 3 companies making every flat screen tv or monitor on the planet. With Soft Drinks, the big brands will recalibrate their machines in between shifts or cleaning and the soda's that continue to come out aren't properly balanced, so they label them as something else and sell it anyway to keep waste to an absolute minimum and to maximize profits.

Fyi, products being made in the same factory and marketed as different brands isn't exclusive to food. I work in a pharmacy and some of the branded and generic medications are exactly the same, in different boxes. Not all of them mind you, some use the same active ingredients but different inactive ones, so be sure to ask your pharmacist if you know you have allergies. For the same reason, try different generic brands too, if you're not finding the one you're using too effective (I find this with one of my migraine meds). You could be saving a lot of money by doing this! (Favourite example is panadol [Americans call it acetaminophen]: brand-name for 96 tablets will be about $15-$20. Generic brand for 100 tablets is $2-$3. The generic tablets are round and not quite as easy to swallow, but if you don't have trouble with that, it's an amazing about of money to be saving)

anyone here who ever tasted Tab X-tra? it was the Norwegian version of Tab and was sold in Norway, Sweden and Finland and was Coca Colas answer to Pepsi Max, i remember it well... its bottle was a unique very hard plastic bottle that when recycled was not crushed and remade to new bottles, they washed the bottle and used it again leading to bottles getting a rather worn look and very easy to identify recycled vs newly produced bottles, and the soda itself... it tasted good innitially as you got it in your mouth, but befor you where even able to swallow the only taste you would be able to feel was a rather distastefull strong taste of chemical artificial sweetener that would last long after forcing yourself to swallow the soda and a little bit of your own vomit as you no doubt woul vomit a little due to the strong chemical artificial sweetener after taste making the next mouthfull that much harder to endure, some people really liked it though and the soda lasted for 13 years (1994-2007 in Sweden and Finnland and a hard to understand 27 years (1994-2021) in Norway.  and i think it could be a fun video where they taste test Diet Colas from other countries.

I have a bad experience with sodas myself. I used to drink it all the time, mainly Coke, and by the time I reached 50, I had lost almost all my teeth. I currently have 3 teeth left. I blame it on all the sugar, but there's also the carbonation which works like acid to soften the teeth, making it easier for the sugar to get in there and create cavities. Although diet sodas don't have the sugar that regular sodas do, I've heard that diet sodas are actually worse because some of the artificial sweeteners have been linked to causing health problems themselves. I only drink water now.  Also, I grew up in Iowa where it is called pop, but I moved to Tennessee later in life and here they call everything coke or cold drink. It was confusing. I just call it soda now.

Well I used to work for Kroger. I can absolutely confirm that all brands under the Kroger label have identical product with different packaging for the market it is shipped to. Ie. Kroger and Fred Meyers and All other subidiaries have the same products just under a different label. I am from Georgia.........aka the state where Coke started........Safe to say all sodas are literally cokes. Or you name the exact soda you want. I drink a lot of diet sodas myself... However, it should be noted, they are terrible for you(as are drinks made with corn syrup).  Sodas in general are acidic and bad for your teeth.   Artificial sweeteners are where diet sodas get even worse, though. Those sweeteners have been shown to still cause insulin spikes. They're destructive to gut biomes. The increased sweetness also tends to increase binge eating/snacking. Diet sodas have also shown evidence to be disastrous for dental health (think meth teeth).  Thankfully, some sodas are starting to offer real sugar, again, but sodas as a whole, aren't great for you. Show restraint, and moderation.

How did you get fountain soda as the best? It's almost always the worst for me. Usually I find that: can = 20 oz or smaller bottle > 2-liter bottle > fountain.  *Then again,* you've missed something in your testing. Cans and small bottles are assumed to be drunk from the container, while 2-liter and fountain are prepared to be poured into a cup, not to mention that half the time when you do fountains no two fountains use the exact same amount of syrup. Ergo since you poured them into a cup to test the various diet cokes, you did the can a disservice.

Coca Cola light, aka Diet Coke, quit out of Finland some years ago. Strictly speaking, in 2019, but the decline of Light Coke started already in 2006. Light Coke was not a success in Finland because it tried to be a feminine equivalent of Coca Cola Zero for women. The difference between Coca Cola's Finnish version of Zero and Light was that Light was sweetened with sucralose and aspartame, while Zero is sweetened with acesulfame K and aspartame.

D: it's called 'soda pop'  so both A and B are valid as shortened names for the same thing.  the name comes from how it was originally created, sodium bicarbonate (baking soda) and vinegar with water which would be sealed in a glass container and shacked. soda coming from one of the ingredients used and pop from the sound of the cork when it was opened.

Diet coke is just coke with added more water.. Sugar addiction works like cocaine addiction... Sudden surge of massive amount of glucose in the brain given you the rush, but after the effects you'd get more sluggish & in more need of sugar, as a patient of adrenal insufficiency & prediabetes, I first had to quit coke & cake.. It wasn't easy, I often dreamt of drinking coke & after waking up I'd want to drink.. I could see clear only after drinking honey water only lasted for 10-15min as I was confined in ned, I was ill, I had to quit coke and I did.. my doctor told me I'm already half way there.. I'm still struggling, but I don't have blurred vision, difficult breathing, anxiousness now.. I can walk & work moderately not bedridden, I couldn't quit processed sugar completely, but I eat definitely less than before..hope I'll be able to get active like before..

Fun fact: my grandmother used to work at a large dairy factory where they produced sliced and blocked cheeses. They packaged products for Kraft, Sargento, great value, and multiple other generic brands. When they needed to produce a specific brand, they would stop the production and just switch out labels. It is literally all the exact same cheese. So, MatPat, you are correct. That generic pasta is exactly the same as the name brand pasta.

Where I grew up in the north west of the UK we always refer to the drink by the specific brand (coke, fanta, dr pepper etc) and only when the brand is unknown or generic we call it a fizzy drink. My grandparents from Bury, near Manchester occasionally say pop but it is a word I have always associated with older people or rural areas. Soda is an almost exclusivley american term in the uk and I was incredibly surprised the first time I heard a brit say it, apparently it was normal in their specific town in the south but I do kinda find that hard to believe.
We call them Soft Drinks in Australia

Yes, this really happened. It was a bunch of theater kids.

Remember, there are theories out there that the reason in the pepsi challenge that pepsi beat coke whereas people might actually prefer coke when drinking a full can/bottle is due to sugar content--pepsi is higher so first sip feels better, but coke is better for full sized as the sugar start to wane off and build up and feel bad. Now, I have no idea if this is actually true. However, this would mean that sip comparison is *not* the whole story.  So to do this properly, you need to do a second round where you first desensitize/saturate yourself of the sugar, by downing say 300-500ml of whatever soda first. Sip test after that should reasonably reflect full serving taste preference.

im from Finland and here (or at least, what i have been grown up to), we call it limsa (some call it limu, some call it limppa), which is a short for limonadi, which comes from the english word lemonade (shocker, right?). but i pretty much only drink coca-cola (coca-cola zero to be specific), (which btw, here in Finland, is shortened as kokis) so when speaking english, im most often saying coke, but if i were to speak of the.. well, lemonades in general, i'd say soda. but i never really liked the term soda. here in Finland, sooda refers to the carbonated water. and im much more fond of the shortened version of lemonade, limsa. maybe i should start calling them by the finnish names limsa and kokis (or cocis) when speaking english :D but no one would probably understand what im saying :D

I actually have been drinking big k (kroger soda) for a few years. I just don't drink diet. I can't drink much soda so I will put the open can back in the fridge and drink the rest a day or 2 later. You probably already know that name brands go flat almost immediately.  I was very pleasantly surprised when I went to drink big k the next day and it was still fizzy. I tested this and the big k sodas depending on the flavor can hold their fizz for days.  If you're really wanting to test if they're the same you could see if the fizz in yours stays after a few days.

So here is something about Stevia, a personal anecdote. I once tried to make brownies with it. It did NOT go well. I looked up the Stevia to sugar ratio to get how much Stevia to use and made up for the less dry ingrediants going in the mix with more flour and Coco powder ect. Slapped it in the recipe as you do. And something.... was wrong.... I baked it, as I normally do. and... The "brownies" if you could call them that... began to... leak? Something about Stevia, I can only guess, makes them not mix with butter at ALL, cause that was the only wet oil thing in the mix. What I ended up with was... this chocolate-ish sweet but kinda burnt hard tack coated in a thin layer of oil from all the butter that (while perfectly blended in to the mix mind you) melted and FLED FOR IT'S LIFE AND LIBERITY from the Stevia. it (the butter) REFUSED to stay mixed in with the rest of the dry, and Stevia is the only difference really in the recipe. When I pulled it out of the oven it was just the choco tack in a puddle of melted butter... I don't do chemistry, and I don't believe in god. but that day I knew as far as baking went. Stevia was the work of Satan or an evil scientists mad machinations. Don't use Stevia for baking. It will only cause you suffering. or at lest, use the recipes of of those brave souls on the front line of the oven who shed tear and took great pains to find out what if any baked goods Stevia works in.
Imtereating factoid, light beer gets its light name because of its reduced calorie count. Convinced that men specifically would'd buy a diet beer, beer makers instead called & marketed it as light beer.

An interesting video, though I must admit I would drink Kombucha over any diet soda. In Australia we call it soda and by the specific brand name or flavouring. Coke is Coke, Pepsi is Pepsi, Fanta is Fanta. Generic/supermarket branded Coke is Cola and Fanta would be orange soda. Doubt this gets noticed but I have an interesting question. Mass distributors like Coke and Pepsi for example will often make a huge variety of flavors and containers. It's something you don't ever notice or see unless you work in the factory itself but not all flavors are marketed or distributed to all locales. For example, I have never heard of or seen Coke Life.  My question is this: How do videos like this, that advertise product variations, affect the marketing and consumer view of the company in whole. Does it elicit more curiosity in new products and open new markets or does it stir resentment in the company for having products I want to try but can't access.

Not all Stevia tastes the same.    The stuff in Zevia (and Zevia soda in general) is awful.  Stevia-in-the-Raw (brand) tastes really good, 'cause it's exactly what it says: un-processed Stevia.  It works really well for tea and coffee. It's not stupidly sweet like Sweet n Low and Splenda, so you have to use a little more.  My newest go-to is the Splenda/Stevia half-and-half product.  As far as commercial soda/pop goes, I cannot have aspartame anymore (developed a bad allergy/sensitivity to it), and ones that use sucralose are few and far between around here, so... *shrug*

Here (in our language) we call it "noshabeh" which if you translate it altogether it does mean soda but fun fact is when you break the word and translate it piece by piece: "noshabe" is a mix of "nosh" and "Abeh". "Nosh" is short for "noshidan" which when translated means "Drinking" and "abeh" or rather say "ab" translates to "water" so in fact, we call our sodas "a water to drink"!!!

[SPOILERS AHEAD] i was rooting for harris teeter i mean, he was just like meant to be a backround character and ended becoming the main character, the most suprising thing is that it was meant to be another diet coke i will now explain this wonderful anime So, MatPat, (the side character obviously) is seeing which diet cola is the best after he took a break from diet cola He decides to make a list featuring 16 colas, 3 Diet cokes, Bottle, can and fountain, coke zero, diet pepsi, pepsi no caffeine, others, diet coke Splenda. He goes to purchase all of these but cannot find diet coke splenda so he just buys Harris Teeter instead because it was in the store. He does several intense matches where the cokes are put up in a fight against who tastes the best, The matches are 1: Diet coke and Publix, with diet coke coming out on top. 2nd match: Boylan vs Sodastream, it's an intense fight but shockingly, sodastream wins after an intense battle. 3rd battle, Diet Pepsi vs. Zevia, it's not an intense fight and diet pepsi EASILY takes the win. 4th match, Diet Rite vs. Pepsi Zero Sugar, Pepsi Zero Sugar wins the battle. 5th battle is Diet Shasta vs. Coke Zero, Coke Zero obviously taking the W,  now the 8th battle is an interesting one featuring the utter noob 365 Zero Calorie cola and diet Sams Cola, Very unsuprisingly Diet Sams Cola takes the win.  Now we enter the quarter finals, first round is really suprising with a really interesting story, Harris Teeter fights against Johnnie ryan, and with alot of shocking twists and turns Harris Teeter takes the trophy. Now food lion fights vs. Diet Pepsi, extremely suprisingly Food Lion beats the big and strong Diet Pepsi. Now we move on to the semi-finals (yes i skipped the first part because i am an idiot and it would make the comment wayyyy to long) Coke Zero destroyed Diet Sams Cola with a single full power taste blast, Diet Coke pinched soda stream and won the battle EASILY. Now, we have 2 family members fighting eachother, Pepsi Zero and Pepsi Caffeine free, Pepsi Caffeine free barely takes the win being very scarred after the battle but quickly healed by medics, Now. 2 Californians fight eachother and the Californians are Harris Teeter and Food Lion, both have the same amount of skill but Haris Teeters IQ plays gave him the win. After that intense battle we have Diet coke vs Diet Pepsi Caffeine Free. Diet coke (the previous winner) wins again! Now Harris Teeter and Coke Zero fight intensley, but they end up in a tie because they managed to satisfy MatPat and a new character Stephanie alot, so they both proceed to the next round. Now it is the final round.... The Championship. Coca Cola zero and Diet cola fight, with Coca Cola Zero defeating Diet Cola but being scarred. Now Harris Teeter was very smart and waited for one of them to fall in battle so they could have an advantage vs the one who won, It was a tough fight but Harris Teeter manages to win. He now has the trophy of Coke wars and is respected by MatPat, that's the entire anime, it was really good i rated it a 10/10

If the citric acid makes the drinks taste especially good, maybe should experiment with adding some good lemon juice to it. Not the dreaded stuff my mother always bought (RealLemon?) from the grocery store, but either from a real lemon or a good brand of organically grown lemon juice like Lakewood or Volcano. The difference between such good brands (no preservatives, lots of serious taste) and the cr*p mom always got is amazing.   The good stuff (just juice from organically grown lemons, nothing else) is not that expensive either. I get 16oz bottles of Lakewood from Krogerâ€™s or by mail order. The taste is good for at least 6 weeks after opening (refrigerate). Itâ€™s much cheaper than lemons in my area.

With the revelation that "Harris Teeter" is really just Kroger, this all makes sense. Kroger is pretty well known for being sort of the secret juggernaut of the soda world. You got your Coke, and Pepsi, and Dr. Pepper, and whatever else slugging it out in the marquee fights, and then there's Kroger just quietly hanging out alongside them, sometimes packing pretty close to the same punch.

Fountain Coke shouldn't have been included as fountain drinks depend too much on the place that you get your cola from. Some have more carbonation than others while some have the syrup to water ratio stronger or weaker. You basically cannot get a consistent fountain cola.

Hey MatPat, as a former maintenance mechanic, I've worked for private label bakers (bread, rolls), snack makers (pretzels, chips), and soda bottlers. I can verify that the soda bottlers typically have a "stock" recipe for each type of soda. Each store chain can have input into how the dials are set for their product. For example, more or less sugar, more or less citric acid, more or less carbonation, etc. So if it's not Coke, Pepsi, Seagrams, 7up, RC, or one of the other major bottlers, its likely produced in a private label facility.

The reason for the difference in taste is pretty simple actually. Plastic always flavors EVERYTHING that is put in it, that is why cans still exist. They are viewed as the more "pure" flavor. The BIGGEST difference though is between the fountain and the others because the sweetener is COMPLETELY different. Fountain soda is sweetened with Sucralose and the other 2 are sweetened with Aspartame. Good on ya Matt Pat for being able to taste the difference

As a life-long Diet Coke drinker, I firmly believe that it was the primary cause of my acid reflux and esophageal erosion. I recommend you don't drink it at all...but if you do, please PLEASE don't drink it past mid-afternoon. You need to clear all that carbonation out long before bedtime.  I've replaced my Diet Coke habit with water flavorings and I can't even go back now. For caffeine, I highly recommend Great Value (Walmart house brand) Pomegranate Lemonade - or for half the caffeine, try the Peach Mango Green Tea. There are other caffeinated flavors...but for me, they're too tart or too sweet to drink all day.

I'll be honest, while I'm not a fan, it's really true, if there is a wide variety of sources for a drink, you'll have a lot of differences in flavor, for instance, fountain against bottle against can. the differences are as follows, fountain actually tastes the sweetest between the three cause it's the most carbonated whereas the bottle can be the most bitter because it has the least carbonation out of the three, it's also why if you leave your bottle of soda out in the sun compared to your fountain drink, the bottle will have gone flat sooner then the fountain drink... if you don't put any ice in the fountain drink that is, which is another thing that adjusts the flavor, if you drink it cold, iced, or hot (and by hot I mean room temp). things to consider drink/soda fans.

Diet Cola is way, way, waaayyyy worse for you than sugary drinks. Both are unhealthy but all these claims of "Zero calories" and "health drink" BS that companies push are all bollocks. One crucial fact that Mat never mentioned was the temperature of these sodas.   In the very first test of Diet Coke: can/bottle/fountain, Mat says fountain has most carbonation. We all know that colder drinks can store more CO2, and that a fountain would come served cold.  What if the canned and bottled Diet Coke were taken off the room temp shelves? What if half these other drinks were room temp too?

Some of it was confusing editing where it seemed like you were saying â€œthat was pleasantâ€ and she said â€œno it wasnâ€™tâ€ meanwhile you were talking about different drinks. I donâ€™t personally think you could beat a 16 cup blind taste test and would LOVE to see you prove me wrong! But having her opinion there influenced your judgment sometimes, it was written on your face and sometimes words. Do a RANDOM short live 16 cup blind taste test where itâ€™s impossible for you to know which cup itâ€™s in , Iâ€™ll turn on notifications for that alone !
Iâ€™m just on the â€œplay in gamesâ€ section and choosing fountain diet cola as a source really isnâ€™t a good idea â€¦ unless you can control EVERY possible variable? Do you have youâ€™re own soda tap in your house that is connected to diet cola syrup and you can be sure that it is full ? That the carbonator (co2 container) is also full? And that the water to syrup mix is exactly the same across the board because you personally set it? The issue with fountain cola is the machine , some places (usually fast food and franchise chains) use more water (by a bit) and less syrup , there is a suggested measurement and then there is their measurement ; each location is different and every cup could be different depending on how much syrup is left in the bag in a box and what % mixture they use. Also you would have to realize that fountain soda loses its flavor and co2 quicker then bottles would and you can always open a fresh can but to use fountain you would have to continuously grab a fountain and drink it within mins to be sure itâ€™s getting a fair chance. I wouldnâ€™t have personally used fountain but used can vs bottle to be sure that the fountain wasnâ€™t the choice solely because whoever you got it from that time had a slightly higher syrup to co2 mixture. Cans and bottles are made the same way every time and while I agree the taste is clearly different (I prefer canned ) fountain is too uncontrollable and could be eliminated solely because itâ€™s flavor is weakened not because the other soda was better. Now if you have a soda tap with Diet Coke in youâ€™re house (which is very possible! ) Then it was fine that you used it in the running. But hey, thatâ€™s just an assessment! My assessment!

Steph is correct; I too grew up in Georgia and Coke was the generic term for all colas. But I grew up in an earlier era than you guys, we also used the term "Co'Cola". Other interesting facts from my era; It was common to feed your baby Coke in their bottle, also in our elementary school we had a Coke machine and every afternoon we had a Coke break where, as a class we would each put our dime in the machine, a Coke cup would drop down, it would then be filled with ice and Coke then we'd take it back to our seat to drink. I think the teachers liked having us drink Coke because it kept us awake after lunch.  In my early 20's I switched to Diet Coke and 50+ years later still only drink Diet Coke. However, last year I did switch to Sodastream due to the convenience but I purchased a 20 lb. CO2 cylinder and an adapter. Now I only pay $30 to fill/refill with food grade CO2 and it lasts a full year and I fill 18 bottles every 2 weeks.  Interesting fact: Sodastream is a subsidiary of PepsiCo and is based in Israel. So when I make my diet cola at their suggested syrup concentration it has a similarly sweet taste of Diet Pepsi which I don't like, therefore I decrease the syrup to give it more of a Diet Coke taste.

So the story, one of many, Soda/Pop/Soft Drink, All has to with alcohol. Back in God know when, Drinks with Heavy amount of alcohol in it Got to be called Beer, Alcohol, Or very rarely, Heavy Drink. But Soft Drinks had very little to no alcohol in it. Ex. Root Beer. There is Root Beer with a little alcohol in it. As well as a few other "Soda", That how Soft Drink came to be, POP came to be about after Soft Drink, People would drink so much Soft Drink they get Drunk on it and end up fighting and well as a Adam West Batman show Punch in the Face you just got "Pop" in the face. .......MUCH later to move away from the alcohol "Pop" was then taken over by the popping Sound of the Drink, and It gave you a popping Feeling. You drink and you feel renewed. as if your Popping with life. And even later down to Forget there was every any alcohol in the drink. "Soda" was given to the drinks to hidden the fact there was every any alcohol.

"That tastes like cough syrup!"  Yeah.. That's what actual cola tastes like. The stuff they sell these days is watered down chemical sugar water without the sugar. And no, Coke was no different when they first came into the market, they've just gotten progressively worse over the years. Ironically the 'New Coke' they put out that everyone seemed to hate was a lot closer to what cola used to taste like, but by then everyone was so used to the heavily diluted taste they didn't even know what actual cola tasted like.

There are also different recipes for the same soda depending on where you live. For example, Coke-a-Cola has a higher concentration of sugar in Florida than it does in Missouri. FYI, my wife worked for a McDonald's distributer... and she found out that the reason that the coke at McDonald's tastes better than other cokes is that they have a special agreement with McDonalds. McDonald's literally puts their coke out differently than any other restaurant. Even the straw they used changes the taste. Mcdonald's has the ideal straw size to optimize the taste.

I'm a little bit puzzled by this episode.  I'm I'm a long time drinker of soft drinks (what we call soda or pop in NZ). In this country, Coca Cola market 3 main sugarless versions of Coke. Your episode only lists the first two.  Diet Cola has been around for decades Coke Zero was the new age replacement but is incredibly watery and bears only a passing resemblance to Coke. Coke No Sugar is the latest iteration.   I've always hated Diet Coke as it tastes like the aluminum tin has been blended into the liquid. Granted the bottle version is less obnoxious.  According to my cousin, Coke zero has been discontinued in Australia however its still readily available here in NZ.   Coke No Sugar is probably the closest taste-wise to Coca Cola. Most people I know including myself consider it the coke of choice. Of course, where possible, I try to support the local brand (L & P No Sugar... and no its not a cola).
I prefer calling it attack helicopter matt But uhhh coke is fine
For the record, Zevia is sodium-free and tastes much better with some salt/electrolytes added.

Fun fact about zero calories. Foods get to advertise as zero calories even if they have calories as long as the amount is small enough. Another factor, the lack of sugars in drinks is commonly swapped with far worse ingredients (like stevia). Only reason to go with a zero callery option is for the marketing.

Answering the question at 15m30s, here in southwest Canada we tend to call carbonated soft drinks "pop" for short.  Calling them all "coke" is just weird.  Although I've also witnessed locally a family who just uses the term "coke" to refer to all soft drinks when talking with their young children, and they didn't get it from the southern US, but rather because Coke is a general favourite and saying say brown coke or orange coke etc was a simpler explanation for young children.

No, my soda tastes run more...Dr. Pepper-y. Although I do love me some Cherry Coke...we (inexplicably*) don't get Cherry Coke in Canada...and the border's been closed for, like, a year. I have one can left from 24 that were purchased during a trip across the border in September 2019. And I'm saving it until I know that it's not going to be the very last can of Cherry Coke I will ever drink (i.e. when the border DOES open and the 'rona is naught but a terrible nightmare from which we have since woken up).  *Ask the question "why is there no Cherry Coke in Canada" and go down a bottomless internet rabbit hole. Nobody seems to know the REAL reason...and the only "official" answer there is, is the unsatisfying "we tried it in Canada in the '80s, and it didn't sell"...which, I mean...C'MON! AFTER 30+ YEARS you don't think you should try again? Like...peoples' tastes haven't changed? I am sure with the right marketing campaign, Cherry Coke could grab some decent market share. Sure, part of that would come out of existing Coca Cola market share...but I think MORE would come from Dr. Pepper and other smaller brands that sell cherry-flavoured beverages. And it's not like the fact that it takes away some Coca Cola sales has prevented them from selling it in any other country...brand diversity is a GOOD THING. Stupid corporate execs thinking that Canadians won't like it enough to justify selling it here....dumb dumb dumb.

Now, I wouldn't encourage ever repeating this excursion due to the intake and experience, however I object to the execution. When going through, while handling them in pairs was perfectly fine, I don't believe you should've known what those pairs were. Being aware of what was what could bias both the active experiment (Such as recognizing that although the clear drink was one soda, thus deducing immediately what the other one was.) and the other results, such as when two sodas are too extremely similar, the decision may be based on the brand rather than the drink itself. Perhaps a bias for or against.  THAT being said, I realize this is all in good fun and the tasting is purely for Mats personal drink-of-choice, so this is more of a footnote than anything, and hardly matters. I'm enjoying the video, and find this whole channel rather pleasant and relaxed.

It's popular to believe that a chemical is going to do all sorts of bad things to you while something natural is going to be more healthy. Unfortunately, this is a load of bollocks. Many natural things are harmful and everything is chemicals.  Some of this stems from people's belief that there's no "free lunch." It seems hard for people to accept that they can cut the calories of sugar and still get the sweet taste. It's humans playing God with nature, so something has to be bad about it, right?  Well, no. Aspartame is incredibly well researched and there's no danger to the average person eating it. Even in doses so large that they're just silly there's no danger. However, there are some people who cannot process it (phenylketonurics; people who cannot process phenylalanine, one of the parts of the Aspartame molecule). This chemical can build up over their life and cause serious health risks. But that's a specific disorder and condemning aspartame because of that group would be like claiming that peanuts give you cancer because some people are allergic.  The other big point that anti-aspartame individuals tend to push is the fact that aspartame breaks down into methanol (i.e. wood alcohol, the stuff that causes you to go blind and die if you drink it), then formaldehyde (used for embalming) and finally formic acid (also known as ant venom). This sounds absolutely terrifying! Surely science has gone too far!!!! ... except it hasn't. The amount of methanol you get from even an excessive amount of aspartame is less than the trace amounts you get from drinking fruit juice.  Other claims that anti-aspartame individuals like to push don't find the need to be grounded in actual scientific fact. For example, there was a study that suggested a link between aspartame and brain cancer... except that the study was flawed and has subsequently been disproven. Conspiracy theorists never let the truth get in the way, though. One incorrectly carried out study is all it takes to prove once and for all that something is true, and any later evidence is just a cover up to keep us from seeing the truth.  In the end people push this claim because it speaks to their fears of science and the unknown. It feels like big business trying to pump us full of who-knows-what (the FDA knows, that's who!) to reap profit from our cold, dead, cancer-ridden corpses. I'm sure some of this fear is helped along by the producers of sugar who can feel the sting in their pocketbooks as people switch to a zero calorie sweetener. Ultimately, though, aspartame is one of the most studied things you will eat all day, and there's been no conclusive evidence that suggests any health disadvantage (except for phenylketonurics) from eating it, even in stupidly large quantities. - u/Koooooj

fun fact, quite often the store brand is made by 1 of the top manufactures , and possibly the one you already buy. They just sell it for a little less under the store name to push more product. My dad worked for a company that provided a generic version that was the exact same product as the more expensive one, just without their brand on it. This was in the day before every store had a store brand.  Usually nothing wrong with the store brand.

What I will say is that if you're trying to replace Diet Coke for health reasons, you can't just drink any other diet cola. They all have similar ingredients. That is, of course not the case with Zevia. The reason why Zevia tasted weird is because of the fact that you're used to Diet Coke. Not only that, you were drinking the other colas right before drinking Zevia. Stevia in general takes time to get used to. I haven't had any soda other than Zevia since June of 2017 and I've gotten used to it. It's sweet once you drink another can. In addition to it not having sugar, artificial sweeteners, or colors, it also doesn't have any of those preservatives shown to cause cancer that can be found in most sodas.

While I appreciate your willingness to try to be impartial on which flavor you prefer, you did give Diet Coke a leg up in the competition off the bat. The Diet Coke qualification round ensured that between bottles, cans, and fountain, the best (in your opinion as the judge) version of Diet Coke would go up against seemingly random versions of the other sodas. Some of them only come in one version (Boylan, for example) but for many of them also have can and bottle versions and the Pepsi products certainly have fountain versions.  I'm a little bummed for you that you couldn't find the Diet Coke w/Splenda version, it's my favorite Diet Coke. I usually pick it up in Target in 12-packs of cans. You may want to glance down the soda aisle next time you're in Target and give it a try.  (Note, drinking HT Zero Calorie Cola as a I write this...)

I grew up in a border city right across California's USA-Mexico Border called Mexicali which is locally famous for its vast CocaCola bottling plant. So, as years went by and after working in the bottling plant itself, I can tell you a few oddities: 1) Consumers, myself included, absolutely LOVE freshly-made Coca Cola, the original, non-diet flavor that is. 2) The container is quite important due to carbon dioxide's diffusivity coefficient through glass, aluminium and plastic (from lowest to highest) - glass preserving that "freshly-made taste" consumers love. 3) And most curious one, Mexican and American flavors of Diet CocaCola and regular CocaCola are switched. I.E. Mexican reg. CocaCola taste just like American Diet CocaCola and viceversa. Don't ask me why. As a former chemist for the QA department, my job was FAR from knowing what the beverageers worked with. Due to most of this, reg. glass-bottled CocaCola is the norm with our southern neighbor. I drink to to now having access to that 11/10 flavor of fresh CocaCola, straight out of the reactor chamber that mixes the reagents into CocaCola.

Diet Coke is based off of New Coke from the 80s.  While people screamed for the "classic" recipe to come back, Diet New Coke instantly became the #1 diet soft drink.  When they switched back to Classic Coke, they kept the New Coke for their diet soda only.  That is why the style of the logo is always been different.  Coke Zero is diet Classic Coke.  I actually like New Coke a little better when it came out, but I was more into things like Mountain Dew and Squirt at the time.  When I started a diet in the early 90s I got hooked on Diet Coke and can not stand Classic Coke any more.  The problem I have with many of the off brand colas is they are based on Pepsi and I hate that too.  Few budget colas took after Diet "New" Coke.  Now I typically prefer Diet Coke from the plastic bottle, but that is because cans are too expensive and fountain drinks are too inconsistent.  The flavor is based on the calibration and cleanliness of the machine.  As for the cola you picked... you could have just look to see if Kroger subsidiaries carry a generic diet soda with citric acid in it.  And with about 5 seconds of looking I found Kroger's Big K Diet Cola...  "Ingredients Carbonated Water, Caramel Color, Phosphoric Acid, Aspartame*, Sodium Benzoate (Preservative), Citric Acid, Caffeine, Natural Flavor"  So it is likely to be the same cola you drank.  I question if I would like it more.  Even though I like fruity soft drinks and such and Diet Cherry Coke... and Diet Dr. Pepper are OK, I hate Lime Coke and pretty much all other fruity colas.  I do not have any Kroger based stores near me and while the name and originator is similar, Fred Meyer and Fredrick Meijer, I am very partial to Meijer and they have their own brand and I think, like Kroger they manufacture quite a lot of their products.  They are the largest privately owned chain.  I do not care for their diet cola one bit.

Personal theory: The reason Steph may have preferred Coke Zero over other diet sodas is because Coke Zero is designed and flavored to be more appealing to people to who prefer the original soda, or non-diet sodas, but are looking to move to diet sodas. I myself started changing to diet sodas recently, and I've found I like the Coke Zero products far more than the Diet Coke (or Coke Light as it's actually called in Europe) products, because Coke Light caters to people who specifically are looking for the diet soda taste, while Coke Zero is made for people who like the traditional Coke taste.

Interesting citric acid, 2 years ago South Africa passed laws on regulating and taxing on the amount of sugar calories in soft drinks. All the brands went basically tweaked their recipes by changing back to sugar from HFCS, lowering the amounts of sugar and jacking up the amount of citric acid. In most brands it made it taste it way better especially Sprite; except Coke which taste A LOT sweeter.

For those who read comments before the video ends, scroll back up. Don't let them spoil the ending. Just trust me.        That being said: I'm not surprise the hipster "artisan" "specialty" "premium" bottle sodas tanked. One of the big things those kind are all about is "real cane sugar" which is indicative of one of the small ways the world is going downhill, as it used to be the default sweetener and now its like this premium thing. In the non-diets, its quite easy for a corn sweetened to get a really jacked taste. IDK about "sugar is sugar" from a health view, or a political one, but cane sugar is far superior to corn in the taste category.  At any rate the old timey themed luxury special sodas lean heavily on that sugar cane bringing the sweet forward so they can get creative with the rest of the flavor to get something different enough that it feels worth the extra dollar. When they try the same formula stacked with aspertaine  or whatever other science chemical, well...Food Theory certainly knows now.  Store brands are used to cutting corners, which means they have been in the corn syrup game longer. The store brands are better with garbage sweeteners, since they are used to NEVER having real sugar, but a science chemical whether diet or not, so the diet soda game is going to be inherently strong

I used to work at a dairy plant for Kroger. If you want organic milk and you see two different products in a Kroger owned store like Fred Meyers. Look for that small Kroger label. Not all of the milk Kroger has in its stores are from the Kroger plant. But if you are deciding between two and they both have the Kroger label. Get the cheaper one. Not always but the majority of the time they both contain milk from the exact same farm or group of farms

One of the coolest things that came out of the Pepsi challenge was that a quick taste can confuse your senses. Pepsi was preferred over Coke a GREAT majority of the time, but sales of Coke went up in response to the taste test. The reason is that Pepsi was sweeter but didn't have the balance that Coke did, and the small sample you were given wasn't enough to make a more informed decision. I wonder if that was an issue here.

In Australia, for carbonated drinks we say soft drink (probably in contrast to a hard/alcoholic drink), in terms of cola you generally either grab a Pepsi or a Coke and half the time you need to check which brand the shop stocks first or you can end up with some awkward stares. There are some more local brands in supermarkets but they are generally treated in line with the store brand products. Not to mention most supermarkets in Australia belong to either of our 2 big supermarket chains so there isn't really any variety there either.

B Soda. From a historic nomenclature angle, it is literally the _only_ right answer. Humans have been calling it "soda water" for multiple *centuries* at least. So there is no grounds for any sort of debate just because people also like to create new slang terminology as they go along through the decades.

In Australia we call them Soft Drinks
I'm from North Carolina as well, and knew that Food Lion was a regional grocery store (as are many grocery stores). So color me surprised when I was travelling to Belgium a couple years ago and sitting down to have dinner and beers and see a Food Lion logo across the street.  After looking it up, we realized that Food Lion is owned by Delhaize (then, now its Delhaize Ahold). They've been owned by Delhaize for almost 50 years now. The Food Lion logo which has always been so memorable to me, was actually taken from their parent company, Delhaize, as the store was originally Food Town but needed to change names due to expanding into other regions where there was a (different) Food Town already in operation. So they went with Food Lion because the parent company had a lion in their logo (and probably other reasons as well).  And that's how I came to find an oddly colored Food Lion logo looking back at me when eating dinner in Belgium, a place I never expected to find a Food Lion logo.

I've heard that people in the south refer to all soft drinks, sodas, pop, as "Coke" but I've never experienced this phenomenon... and I'm from Georgia... two counties away from where coke was INVENTED...in my experience most people around here refer to all soft drinks as "Soda" collectively... I think the confusion about southerners calling ALL soft drinks "coke" likely comes from the fact that when most people from Georgia say they want Coke... They mean they want "Coke" the original"Coca-Cola" because that is *By Far* THE most popular choice... we're not calling all "soda" _"Coke"_ we're refusing to acknowledge most other soft drinks even exist... there is only coke...      ... ... ...and Dr.pepper too I guess ðŸ˜’

I would like to point out that Splenda brand Sucralose is not a healthier Aspartame substitute. It's literally just a brand name for the exact same product. Literally any artificial sweetener is made from Aspartame, you're just looking at a different brand name for the same product. And sorry to tell you, but every diet drink on the market contains Aspartame, you're not suppose to use it because it's actually worse than sugar but they do it anyway because there is no other options for a sweetener other than either Aspartame or sugar.  I had to research this stuff back in high school for a class and I learned way more about this crap than I ever wanted to. Long story short, Aspartame is the reason I would rather drink a regular soda and skip diet entirely.  Oh and to answer your question... Pop is something only people over 60 say. Me, who drinks water; You should just get over soda all together. As they said at the VERY start; it's not that healthy as you think. You guys really should do a theory on diet sodas as a whole, and see if it's REALLY as healthy as they claim they are.
As someone who knows multiple people who have worked in food processing factories of varying kinds including Kellogg's, your store brand non-perishable food items ARE THE SAME as your name brand. So stop overpaying for fancy packaging (especially cereals, don't do that. Buy the bagged stuff with more food for your money.) Buy store-branded foods. I remember growing up with friends who always complained about the store brand foods being of "lower quality" than other foods. And yeah, there is a taste difference due to packaging. But every time, my Dad would say he saw those two different branded foods being loaded onto pallets in the same factory to be sent to the same store for a different price. I find this also interesting when pairing this with one of the earlier theories about grocery stores. Grocery stores will place their store brands lower on the shelves for the sake of getting more interest for the name brand items. It's a thing. But I will always advocate that those foods lower on the shelves are essentially the same as the name brand foods.

Cool the house in CA was spared in the fire, I remember you guys visiting NC doing the fast food and the Pizza theory for Chucky Cheese. I read a great book called "Flavor: The Science of Our Most Neglected Sense" by Bob Holmes that discusses not only the pros and cons of blind taste tests, but hundreds of other factors that can weigh in to our perception of flavor. I found the book not only highly educational but deeply enjoyable, sort of like your videos!  One thing it mentions about taste testing is that the amount you drink as well as the appearance of a soda's packaging can both alter the soda's taste--and that these are both legitimate factors to consider before pronouncing a flavor verdict. For example, if you drink soda out of a yellow can, your brain will interpret your taste buds' readings differently than if you drink out of a red can. And if you drink a whole can of soda, your opinion of its flavor will be different than the opinion you obtain from a single sip.  That's why scientists using a blind taste test to determine whether unbiased people generally prefer Coca Cola or Pepsi better will almost always get the result that Pepsi tastes better--yet the same people who believe it tastes better would often rather drink a whole can of Coca Cola than a can of Pepsi. They observed that sweetness-packed Pepsi produces a potent burst of flavor that makes it shine compared to the relatively non-sweet Coca Cola, but that this burst of flavor tends to tire people's taste buds if they drink too much of it. Coca Cola tires people much more slowly, so some people enjoy drinking a whole can of it (and thus purchasing it) more than they like drinking whole cans of Pepsi.  [SPOILER WARNING] In order to truly know if you prefer Harris Teeter's Cola to Diet Coke, you would need to experience each one's taste in the circumstances and amounts in which you would normally drink soda. In a blind taste test where you sit in front of a camera, take a tiny sip, and purposefully analyze its flavor, your impression of the soda will differ from the impression you get from gradually sipping a whole glass of it while researching and typing the script of your next theory video and performing other everyday tasks. Will a flavor you preferred in a blind taste test exhaust your taste buds after a whole glass? Or will a whole glass of your preferred soda just make it even better?  Yep, that's what happens when I don't have a character limit on social media sites...

There are a few things I'd like to mention that I haven't heard said in the video Firstly is that Coca Cola's recipe changed in 1903 in America (when Coca Leaves,  a main ingredient, were illegalized)  and then changed again in 1985 because they found their business rival pepsi's sweeter taste was more enticing to consumers,  which was reverted in less than 3 months due to public backlash. (Also that Coke and Pepsi are surprisingly friendly as business rivals)  Secondly is the mention of sweeteners (and I intend this to be informative for any diabetics out there with me)  for the sake of your own safety,  avoid aspartame.  It may not be nearly as dangerous for you as regular sugars,  but sucralose is much safer if you're trying to maintain or lower your sugars. This goes for sugar substitutes as well,  it's safe to check and avoid aspartame. I just wanted to spread this out in case any newly diagnosed diabetics ended up reading this.  Stay safe,  friends.  Third is my question of why MatPat is so obsessed with diet cola in general.

A.B.C.D. I dont discriminate in words
Depends where you got the fountain drink from.  Some places use a lower 4:1 ratio of syrup to C02, but if you got it from say a Mickey D's or Wendy's they use a higher 2-2.5:1, allowing more syrup thus making them sweeter.  Places like convenience stores use lower ratios to save on cost.  Meaning, it might taste better, but it might have hidden calories because the extra sugary syrup injected into the fountain.

I Really don't get the Fear around Aspartame? It's NOAEL (No-observed-adverse-effect level) is around 4000mg/kg/day and it's ADI (Advised Daily Intake) is 50mg/kg/Day. So to hit your ADI (About 0.0125% of the NOAEL), a 70kg person would would need to drink 19-20 cans a diet Soda a day (Assuming a single can had 180mg of Aspartame).  All the Fearmongering stems from a study from the 70s/80s where they gave rats and INSANE dose of Aspartame and found it negatively affected their metabolism. But that dose was something stupid like 10G/kg/Day, Using the same 70kg person example as earlier that equates to nearly 4 THOUSAND Cans of Diet coke a Day....  To Sum, you bladder would explode before you drank enough diet soda for Aspartame to have any negative affects.

Here in Saudi Arabia (Riyadh to be specific), people call it Pepsi. Just Pepsi. Almost anyone here will tell you it's called Pepsi until you search for specific brand or flavour. One of the reasons for this is that families here were raised with brands like Coca Cola and Pepsi. Thus remembering the name "Pepsi" and "Coca Cola" while having lunches and dinners. That's with some other brands like Miranda, Fanta, Mt Dew, etc.

matpat you need to ditch the diet beverages.  If you need to drink soda, you should be drinking something that has sugar as an ingredient.  Not high fructose corn syrup, not aspartame, not stevia, not any other replacement. The problem with most diet sodas, for me, is the aspartame. The taste and how they sit in the belly are what make them worse than standard, full calorie sodas or even the aspartame free diets. Of the major brand Diet Colas- #1 Diet Pepsi Aspartame Free (sadly cancelled). #2 Diet Rite. #3 Coke Zero (surprisingly with aspartame) Down at the bottom is Diet Coke and even worse... Diet Coke 'Feisty Cherry'. Drinking THAT is how I imagine drinking battery acid or Drano would be.
If you taste the stevia you have too much stevia. People have a hard time believing how strong it is, so they think they must add more for no other reason than "it can't be _that_ much sweeter!"  You also need an actual underlying flavor to sweeten. Stevia isn't really suitable for more subtly flavored drinks, at least to the American tongue, where sweetness _is_ a flavor, and often a peer flavor...insofar as sweetened could be called a flavor. (It's not...except in the US.)  The upshot is that stevia is hard to properly use in the US thanks to the American sweetness bug. When you're sweetening ketchup and mustard ffs it's a problem. Not to mention, did you know Subway is a pastry shop? Oh, wait, you covered that.

I work for a company that produces vitamins and supplements. We have several private label customers. The bulk (capsules, tablets, or softgels) is the same in the different bottles. We just change the bottle colour or shape and put a different label on. Costco, Shoppers Drug Mart, London Drugs, Walmart, Rexall, Safeway, and Loblaw's brands all sell the same vitamins with different labels.

I use to always pick up cherry or raspberry flavored sodas when I could get them since they were my favorite. Then I went to a smaller convince store around high school every Friday, on my way home, for snacks but they never had cherry or raspberry flavored stuff so I tried out different sodas and found out I really liked Dr. Pepper (turns out some of the 23 flavors are raspberry and cherry). Then I started to notice how much Dr Pepper was($3 a 2L bottle in my town) and decided to try some of the supermarket brands of Dr Pepper knock offs. I will say, I have tried Walmart, Safeway, and Fred Meyer Dr. Whatevers and I like Fred Meyers more, and the best thing is that the 2L bottles are around 85 cents vs walmart's 95 cents and Safeway's $1.25.

I don't drink anything other than water, and occasionally some juice if it's fresh and with no sugar. Not because I'm against that or anything, in fact, I have a bit of a sweet tooth. It is mainly out of spite. TO add some context, in my teens I used to be the type of guy who would buy a 2L coca-cola to drink by himself in a day. So one day when I was 17 my family and I went out to eat, but last night I saw one of those videos about how sodas are bad and all, I remember it cause it had a song by Jason Mraz and all, it was called the real bears. So while ordering I tell my family I don't want a soda, and later when my sister couldn't finish hers she tries to give it to me, but I say I'm gonna stop drinking sodas. Now they knew that I love them so they simply laughed and laughed.   And out of the sheer desire to prove them wrong, I stopped and months later they realized. Now its been 8 years and I still shove it in their faces, even though they are happy for me for trying to be healthier.

I can't stand the taste of aspartame, so I never got into the diet coke fad. I got some flavor mixes for water, and I had to toss them out after the first use. I guess it isn't too bad, though, aspartame has been linked to some minor short-term memory loss. As with most science there are different results, depending on what you search for(terminology affects search results and can lead to biased results). Also, fountains tend to add a bit extra syrup to compensate for any ice that may be present. This is so that by the time you get to the bottom it's not too diluted. As someone who works in food manufacturing as well as custom food manufacturing (small company producing extra product for a big company), I can tell you that there are  a lot of exactly the same products you can get cheaper from a different brand.  For instance, sargento brand shredded cheese and Kraft shredded cheese are exactly the same. The same ingredients in the same amounts just made on a different set of machinery because sargento wants it that way.  Also, if you know of the turkey brand Jennie-o, their turkey bacon is exactly the same as great value turkey bacon just with a different label (and a little "looser" quality standard but that's neither here nor there) but I think that more location specific.

All Pop is Soda, but not all Soda is Pop. Soda is just carbonated water, where Pop specifically refers to carbonated water with sweetener and flavoring. Think of the same difference as liquor vs liqueur.

As someone who grew up drinking Diet Coke, this was an interesting one. Even more interesting knowing that Kroger, which was initially a small company in the Midwest that got bigger as I got through school, technically owns a bunch of smaller chains. I still have family living in the area where Kroger can be found. I'll report back in the future if I get to try their diet coke. I also did some digging and apparently Kroger uses some specific manufacturing plants. One is America's Beverage Co. and manufactures soft drinks in Texas, and one is Springdale Ice Cream & Beverage in Ohio. Your soda may depend upon which manufacturing location is closest.

Soda fountain drinks vary based on the settings in the dispenser. I would've gone with a can/bottle only competition to reduce that variable. So kinda a side thing and this may be opinion...I think Fountain Soda always tastes better then Can or Plastic/Glass bottle. My thought on why this is...is that with Fountain Drinks it's mixed right there and then as you pour it. With Bottle and Can it's mixed before hand and then sealed like that till it's open meaning it sits around for longer. So with fountain you're basically getting "Fresh" soda.

Please no with the aspartame pseudoscience sourced from Wikipedia, MatPat. The bans on it are ridiculous. It's a dipeptide of aspartic acid and phenylalanine that dissociates into those constituent amino acids in your stomach. Unless you have phenylketonuria, it is not a concern.   Support science, not fearmongering.

I might regret this suggestion depending on how it turns out, but maybe a good Food Theory episode could be one for powder drink mixes meant to add flavor and vitamins to bottles/pitchers of water? To curb the "need" to get a flavorful, but sugar-loaded soda whenever went out to eat rather than settling for water when was younger, had tried opting for a cheaper substitution of one of these local grocery store colas.   However, while it solved the cost issue of getting that soda fix, it didn't solve the sugar content issue. So to solve THAT, after seeing it in an isle I'd decided to try out these artificially flavored, 0-sugar drink mixes. I cared more about the drink being flavorful, than it needing to particularly be the flavor of soda. But was it really the healthier option, given the highly artificial nature of it? Or is the health benefit of these mixes not nearly as effective as expected?

Fun fact: the taste of fountain soda is never consistent, as the fountain mixes components from several bottles to make the soda and pour it into your cup. which means sometimes one component will run out and the soda will taste awful, or that each machine mixes the components differently
I've never understood the point of drinking diet sodas. They are FAR more unhealthy for you than a normal soda, and in fact, have actually been linked to more cases of obesity than normal soda, as well as having many artificial sweeteners that have been linked to cancer. Ditch the diet soda, and just find a regular soda that you enjoy. The risks that come with drinking diet sodas far outweigh the calories "saved".

As a former Harris Teeter employee: yes, the HT brand items and the Kroger brand items are the same things just with different labels. Sometimes, it's not even labeled differently. The Simple Truth, Simple Truth Organic, Pet Pride, Luvsome, and Private Selection brands are found in both stores. (There might be more, I don't remember all of the HT brands.) When the pandemic hit and we ran out of HT brand rice, we had Kroger rice on our shelves instead. Same thing, different label.

In Australia we call it soft drink.  I think its overqrching for all the different flavours of soft drink or *soda* that we have. Theres 2 main orange flvrs 'sunkist' and 'fanta', then a strawberry/raspberry one from Kirks' 'creaming soda', grape is 'pasito' and Passiona is passion fruit...supposedly. And it wouldnt be australia without having 5 completely different soft drinks for 1 flavour: flavr being lemon and the brands are Sprite, Lemonade, Lift and Solo. Oh and theres also 7up.   As a kid I would generally make 'punch' with orange juice and Kirks' lemonade, or use any of the classic Golden Circle fruit juices like pineapple and lemonade, tropical punch & lemonade or golden pash with lemonade.   We do have mountain dew and coke and pepsi because america actually influnces us quite a bit when u think about it.
Stevia is such a hit or miss product. I did find some that is pretty good, but most stevia sweetened products are gross

when I was a kid, it was all pop. however, we also had cordials, which we didn't call pop, they were concentrated fruit juice drinks which require you to dilute with water first. lime cordial, orange juice, orange squash, hi juice from concentrate, cartons of orange juice concentrate, each all different drinks which had wildly different flavors, you could have 6/7 orange based drinks in the house that none tasted similar to one another, like sunny D, capri sun, hi juice orange, concentrated juice drink, orange squash, fruit n barley orange, actual oranges. Robinson's' orange juice, which tasted different from home brand names so that would also count as a different orange, each of the oranges from each store tasted distinctly different from one another as well, morrisson's tasted better than asda, aldi and lidl tasted different, the' job lot' which was an independent store had orange that tasted different yet again. iceland,  fulton foods, convenience stores, all had different tasting orange juice. Tesco's tasted more like orange peel than the rest.

On a related note and a heads up for anyone planning of getting off of sodas for health reasons: It is entirely possible that if you have been drinking soda for years your body might not produce enough acid on its own anymore. In order to stop having late night stomach problems I had to start drinking seltzer water. Alternatively you can regularly drink vinegar based drinks if you do develop this problem.

Mat: Me: WHO ARE YOU AND WHAT HAVE YOU DONE WITH MATPAT?
Sucralose is different than sucrose through the substitution of a chlorine atom. This makes it so your body can't break it down, but it still releases insulin. Since insulin can't break down sucralose, this often leads to increased weight gain compared to sucrose as well as the increased build up of insulin in the body giving a higher chance of becoming diabetic. Aspartame doesn't release insulin, so these effects aren't seen with that sweetener. Sucralose is even worse for you if you don't eat much sugar. If you still consume sugar, the insulin can still have a small use, but without the sugar, the insulin can just sit in your system without being used.
Honestly, unless I really look for the differences between all the types of Coca-Cola, Coke (same thing), Pepsi, Pepsi Max, and other verients of the Coke flavour, they all fast the same, but I prefer Coca-Cola, just because. Also same with the Lemonade, Sprite and other ones. Except solo, that's different. Oh and with Fanta/Sunkist/Other orange soft drinks, and all the raspberry flavours as well (raspberry Fanta /shweeps (forgot the spelling) raspberry soft drink, ect.)

Amateur... let me educate your meagre Diet Coke palette :D  Diet coke also tastes different per country due to different countries using different sweetener (you mention, but still). For example, i love Australian DC (Aspartamine), but hate Malaysian DC (Splenda)... because of the sweetener is different... BUT IT GOES FURTHER See, different countries also have different water sources, and the water source itself can determine the taste of the Diet Coke. Sometimes the water is from the mains, thus is pre-treated, other times it can before a bore, which will be determined by the mineral composition. BUT THERE IS MORE Diet coke has a shelf life of about a year before it goes bad. During this time the optimum age is 9 months before the "use by" date. however usually it is not on the shelf till 6 months before the use by date (depending on location).  As you go from 6 months to the use by date the taste gradually gets worse, and this is exaggerated by heat. two Diet cokes the same age can taste different if one was left in heat, even if both are chilled at time of drinking.  So... you appear to be missing A LOT

I am shocked that fountain Diet Coke won the play in game. While there is an obvious noticeable difference between the bottle, can and fountain, there is an extremely wide spectrum of fountain. Also, it is calibrated to pour at a certain temperature in a cup with ice. Also, depending on the water source, the taste will be different. McDonalds has the best Diet Coke fountain because they have a patented water filtration system. They also clean and calibrate often.

18:19 Matthew and Stephenie sharing one brain cell.
Regarding stevia, a lot of it is accompanied by a substance called Erythritol, which might be what you don't like as opposed to the stevia itself. And yes, there is a difference in taste between stevia with and without erythritol. Taste isn't the only issue: some people's digestive systems also have trouble digesting erythritol.

@17:28 Literally hard lesson to learn as a kid, when you find out your allergic to Citric Acid. It's in everything, it's so hard to avoid. I can have it at small quantities but if I have to much if it too close together I get sick. Where the same amount a normal person is fine. Like super sick. When it's a product that's not food that has Citric acid, I have to avoid it entirely. Anytime a friend has a makeup person or I go to the Salon U have to tell the people there I can't use any products with Citric Acid.

This affects not only the taste, but the entire drinking experience itself. Individuals may have carbonation level preferences. Source: I've drank a heckuva lot of diet soda in my lifetime.

I believe that you totally invalidated your whole comparison test. By choosing Diet Coke from a fountain, you are drinking something that is not exactly replicated regularly. A fountain soda (yes, SODA; pop is your dad) comes to the food service location as syrup. It is mixed in a soda tower, set up by people. This in and of itself can lead to slight unintentional imperfections in the mix. For example, how firmly the tube is connected to the nozzle in the syrup box can affect exactly how much syrup is dispensed for each serving. Before it is mixed with the carbonation, the water flows up through tubes which are cooled by the ice towers. The amount of cooling affects the amount of carbonation. Even the pressure on the lever which is pressed by the server can affect the overall outcome of the mix. There are just too many variables for a fountain drink to be used in a comparison test. (Disclaimer: I really do not know if there are multiple ways different soda towers work. However, drinking diet colas pretty much my whole life has made me very aware that a cup of soda from one location can taste totally differently from a cup of soda from another)  Besides. Coke Zero is the clear winner in a taste test challenge!  ðŸ˜‰

I would like to point something out. It's so often said "it's fRoM tHe saMe FaCtOrY" like that means it's the same product. Those factories follow the recipes you give them.  They are bound by contract to keep those recipes proprietary. They make one product, then switch to another. They don't just switch labels. Think about the products that leave your kitchen. The recipe/ingredients dictate far more than the location, right?

From the time I was a kid until age fourteen, I used to drink a flat of President's Choice Cola every week or two. Though by fourteen, I had a ton of health issues and my insides felt like a corkscrew. I briefly was a Lipton tea soda person until I found my new passion: Craft beer (and Coke Zero). So, I switched my 5 PC Colas a day to 2 Craft beers a day and a couple of Coke Zeros a month, yes I was underage drinking. Kids, don't underage drink, it was just a big thing where I came from, like starting at a certain age, parents expected you to drink with them.   Then, seven years ago, I went really healthy, I started gradually watering my Coke Zero down with San Pelligrino until I was drinking straight San Pell. Now, I drink San Pellegrino most often but will have a Coke Zero every seven months or so. I have no regrets, in fact, I feel great!
Granted I havenâ€™t tried Harris Teeter diet cola, but Iâ€™m definitely with Steph here; Coke Zero is undoubtedly better than Diet Coke.ðŸ‘€

Yeah... you really can't go farther east or south than Florida WITHOUT sacrificing more of south or east, respectively, than you gained of east or south. A few states are, in whole or in part, farther east than Palm Beach Shores, but you have to go farther north to get to them than you went east; only part of Hawaii is farther south than Key West, but you have to go farther west to get to it than you went south. (Yes, you could go the other way in both instances, but that distance is even farther.)  There used to be a Food Lion in my city. Now the nearest one to me appears to be in Savannah, Georgia. Technically, the closest one's in Waycross, Georgia, but the closest one in my state is, again, in Fernandina Beach. I love the channel, been watching since it started.  However a couple of comments on this.  Comparing a fountain pour to cans or bottles is not a valid test.  Mat pointed it out himself, the method of delivery affects the taste.  Only a few of these are available as a fountain beverage, so it would be interesting to see a head to head on those via fountain pour.  Also, as a user of Soda Stream, that is an extremely variable experience even with a single flavor.  You fill the bottle with water to the "Max Fill" line. Do you use filtered or from the tap?  You measure out the syrup "to suit your taste".  You add the carbonation by pressing a button "X" number of times for "X" number of seconds, again according to  preference.  All  points where a slight change one way or the other affects the flavor of the final beverage.   And...just as an aside..."soda"...and I rank Diet Coke at pretty much near the bottom with Coke Zero at the top.  At least among straight up colas.  Step  outside of that lane, then give me a diet Dew or Dr. Pepper.

D - Fizzy :3
I live in Sweden and a few years. OK so quite a while back, a consumer show that aired on national TV did a test much like this. The big difference was that they didn't tell the panel what any of the Cokes were, so no one knew what they were tasting, or if it even was different products in the glasses. So it was as close to a blind test as they could get. They to ended up with a store brand Cola in the top slot. The interesting thing was the number of people who wrote things like "There's nothing like the original!" and other similar things. I think it was something like 70 or 80 % who was convinced that they had picked the original Coca-Cola, and the majority of those claimed that their second choice wasn't even close. I tried the store brand and I can't say I think it was better than original Coca-Cola, but then I had to pour it out of the extremely cheap and flimsy plastic bottle seeing the very cheaply designed label on the bottle and that might have influenced me more than I'd like to admit. I also have a feeling that the quality varied a lot more than what original Coke tends to do. But again, this might have been influenced by the poor quality of the bottles and labels.
In the northeast we have the grocery store shop rite which also has some pretty good store brand products.

A
So for Mat, Stephanie, and anyone else who is interested as to why soda tastes different depending on the container: The container that the soda is in changes the flavor. I don't know how it works entirely because I'm not a chemist, nor have I done any real research into this topic to back this up, but based on what little I do know about basic chemistry, specifically acids, I think it has to do with the acidity of soda and the slight breakdown on the inside surface of its container. Coke is acidic enough to be classified as a low power drain cleaner, so it makes sense that it would be just powerful enough to breakdown the inside surface of the container it's in given enough time. That is why you can taste the difference between canned soda, bottled soda, and fountain soda. Canned has a slight metallic taste, but it's not as noticeable as plastic because plastic is easier to breakdown than aluminum. That's why glass bottles have a slight difference too. Glass is harder to breakdown than aluminum, so it has less of impact on the flavor than a can. Finally, that's why fountain soda always tastes the best. While it's just as acidic as it's canned and bottled counterparts all forms of soda are very weak acids, otherwise I donâ€™t think it would be safe for human consumption. Either way, fountain soda hasn't had enough time to start breaking down the inner surface of the cup it goes into because it's mixed right there at the machine. It's literally carbonated tap water and syrup, no plastic, metal, or even glass erosion additives.  Maybe I'm wrong, since I am not an authority on this subject, but this is my theory anyway.

My mom actually worked for Food Lion in Tennessee for 20+ years, so seeing it appear on the list brought a bittersweet moment on for me.  It was much of my childhood, always being around the store whenever mom couldn't find a babysitter, but also it was a point of contention as she was unfairly fired for a health condition- she had surgery on her Achilles Tendon and needed a medical 'boot' in order to walk.  When she was told by her district manager that she couldn't wear it around the store, well her performance took a noticeable dip- as one who could barely walk would have had.  They then fired her for it- citing 'too many sick days/medical leave'.  She died from a heart attack in her sleep half a year before the class action lawsuit finished up in courts.  Side note: Food Lion lost.

Actually heard of Food Lion. One used to be here years ago, but it closed down in the 90s.  I was too young to think or investigate much about the store that was suddenly gone, and had a telephone game style answer of "explicit Instructions from corporate told them to just discount expired items, and they did this until it was obvious just looking at it, sparking an investigation and getting places shut down."  I also don't like inaccuracies and try to challenge my own biases, so I looked up the details. My local branch closed years after the actual controversy, and I was probably just misremembering the way my mother put why she didn't shop there or something. People reacting that way is part of why such allegations are a serious issue to companies.  The reality, according to Wikipedia, was ABC did an investigation and released footage of various unhealthy practices from employee-only areas. Like using nail polish to remove expiration dates from dairy products, repackaging expired meat, not following proper cleaning procedures, ETC. Food Lion didn't bother fighting the allegations, but did take them to court on easier charges for breaking the contracts they would need to have signed and duties they need to have agreed to to get into those areas as employees, and through the court case unearthed dozens of hours of footage where the ABC people tried to push employees into breaking proper procedure, and they didn't do it.  This has nothing to do with you or this video. I just got distracted and into doing a quick search for information on the Food Lion controversy after your comment made me think of it for the first time in years.

Ok but all jokes aside, like I said, I work at harris teeter and yeah. Our company works with others and having worked at grocery stores that are tied with Kroger. They're all basically the same thing. They come from the same manufacturer and the only time It'll ever be different is if your item from Harris teeter has the word "Harris teeter traders" on it. It's a different manufacturer that mainly focuses on organic products. However like how Mat said in this video, the basic HT products are identical to other grocery stores since making them in one manufacturer keeps cost low.
