To be completely fair, the drinks that had the fruit add-ins like Diet Cola with Lime were not allowed. So the fact that MatPat liked the local diet cola for having that fruity taste sort of negates the victory if you're willing to argue that even though it has the fruit flavor by default, it still has the arguably unfair advantage. We need a rematch between this cola and a similar Diet Coke (+fruit), just to be completely fair. I'd also argue that this competition would have been about 75% more scientific if they had used water or something as a pallet cleanser between tastes. Just swish it around then spit it out to clear the taste of other drinks out before doubling down. You never know if having one drink still on your tongue tainted the flavor of the next drink. I doubt the results would be altered too much, but I'm here for the science, damnit.

Iâ€™m very curious about how you did the fountain pop. Because over time, the flavour of pop will change as it degasses. Fountain pop usually degasses a lot faster than pop kept in a bottle or a can because it does not keep the pop under pressure. So if you used the same source for the fountain pop throughout the tests, there is potential that the fountain pop was better at the beginning than at the end.

I tried to like Stevia as its supposed to be healthier but it tasted really, really disgusting to me. I couldn't understand why so many people loved it and claimed it had a pleasant, sweet taste. I could even tell when a product uses it as a sweetener without being told as it tasted horrid to me. Speaking of store brands, Food Lion had some of their snack foods on an endcap for sale and I grabbed a few because snacks while working, and my god they are better than the Little Debbie name brand.  The only thing the Little Debbie does better is the consistency of the product. The Food Lion oatmeal cookie creme sandwiches almost always have cream on the inside of the wrapper, the chocolate covered peanut butter wafer bars the chocolate will sometimes pop off a square or two of the top wafer or it'll be super coated.  But they are just as if not more delicious than the name brand while being cheaper. Like the oatmeal sammiches, firmer oatmeal cookies. The nutty buddy bars are more flavorful. The swiss rolls have a better balance of creme and sponge.

i have a mini theory about why matt pat really likes the harris teeter brand. the reason being its different. he's been drinking diet coke for a LOOOOONNNGGG time, and eventually people will get bored of repetetive foods and drinks, just ask my dad who ate nothing but pasta, ground beef, and tomatoes with no seasoning everyday for three years. sure, that combination is the most unoffensive thing in the entire world, but it got old really quick, and more related to the video, its why eating too much candy can make you not want to eat any because it gets boring. So something that reminds matt pat of his favorite drink, yet changes it up a bit to add interest, would be more appealing. Us humans like diversity and new things, so it makes sense why Harris Teeter would be Matt pats new favorite

A fucking ton of their generic stuff is amazing, often being better than the big name stuff. the best part is that it's for the generic product price. you can't get me on diet sodas though. every diet soda is disgusting. also, i'm surprised you picked the diet coke from a fountain. most of the time fountain drinks are terrible because the mix is always off and inconsistent between locations and even day to day operation of one place. good mythical morning found that canned sodas were almost always the best source and i agree for their reasoning. cans do tend to hold on to that extra fresh bite in the carbonation which really sets it far above other sources where it leaks out like crazy. they also tested glass bottles too so they had 4 sources. they originally thought the glass bottle would be the best, but then the cans rekt that theory. but that's just a theory. a comment theory. thanks for reading.

On another note, this episode actually has some WEIRD connections to my life.  Like, knowing about Food Lion despite not living in NC is one thing.  Only reason I'm familiar is because our family likes to vacation on Topsail Island, where that's the main grocery store.  But it's been YEARS since I heard the word "aspartame".  My mother is a fellow Diet Coke lover, and my father would occasionally have some, but it cause him pain afterward.  Turned out he was allergic to aspartame, and so we had to switch to the Diet Coke with Splenda you mentioned.  It was a dark day in our household when the local store stopped stocking it.

Wait a minute. MatPat's preferred Diet Cola now is basically fricking Kroger's Big K? I remember drinking that forever ago as a kid because for a time my mother was in lower paying jobs. We got Big K instead of Coke, but I didn't like it as much then. Maybe they've changed stuff since then. It won't replace Diet Dr. Pepper or Root Beers for me, but I'd try it out if I get an itch for a diet cola.  Edit. First my mother got Big K Cola because she thought it was better, not because we were poorer. Oops on my part. Second, I finally tested my taste buds against Big K Diet Cola and fountain Diet Coke. I gotta say that if Harris Teeter is the same as Big K, then I say it's the better cola. However, I don't think it's the citric acid. Both Big K and Coke have citric acid in them. I instead purpose that it's not the citric acid but the carbonation that they use. To explain my FOOD THEORY I'll tell a story. Before going back to diet sodas after cutting and soda from my diet, I tried A&W brand mix with carbonated water. Tasted just like A&W root beer. I was using a Nestle brand of water for the mix, but when they didn't have any I used the Kroger brand of carbonated water. Weirdly to me then, I preferred the Kroger brand. Since it was cheaper and better, I just bought it instead. Now that I had Kroger's Big K Diet Cola, I can easily confirm that the carbonation is identical to their carbonated water. Now there might be more to it of course, but the fact that Kroger carbonation seem to not only be consistent but BETTER than others is something I can't overlook. But hey that's just my theory, my FOOD THEO- ok I'll stop right there.

You cant have fountain, bottle, canned cokes poured into a glass and then tasted, that ruins them all....you have to blind taste them with someone else holding them via straw, GMM did this and tried to vote based off of it, unfortunately, depending on the source, as soon as you re-pour, it loses tons of bite, and flavor....gotta redo it the right way without ruining your samples.  Same thing with them being open air....depending on how long they sit open air, they also lose more, so if you pour them and wait around to get to them, it ruins the samples.

Years ago i came up with a food theory about diet coke myself - everyone who i saw drink it regularly seemed overly confident and enthusiastic in what they do. Mat  Pat was one of them, but also my favourite high school teachers, my aunty and one of my uncles. Which seemed weird, because diet coke is definitely an acquired taste. One of my new housemates noticed the same thing.  As a joke I started to drink diet coke more often when I was asked if i wanted soft drink, "so some of that confidence could rub off on myself". Then I started drinking it after running in the morning everyday, and now that's transformed to having it for breakfast regardless if I run before then or not. Now I'm pretty much drinking it unironically and actually like it. I had some while watching this video (over breakfast).  Has anyone else noticed the same thing about people who drink diet coke? Would love to see a food theory episode on it :P

I typically prefer fountain soda unless it's Baja Blast which is typically fountain exclusive but it's one of those, if you get the mix wrong, it ruins the whole thing so when it's available in the cans & bottles, I'll typically buy a few bottles of it because I go for plasticy over tinny any day. I'm a regular Coke drinker for the most part & I like fountain Coke so much that I can identify which Coke comes from where like when I was a kid, Red Robin was one of my favorite restaurants for not only the decor but because their Coke was consistently good. They remodeled & Happy Panda because my favorite because good Coke & amazing sweet & sour sauce but that changed when they got new ownership, pretty much any restaurant I enjoy gets ruined at some point lol. McDonald's Coke is an easy one to tell apart from the others because it kind of tastes just a tad watered down but that actually works for it in my opinion because on the occasion where they can make that cola flavor stand out more, it's fantastic. I found a McDonald's where I recently moved to that has had better Coke than usual so that makes me happy. On the flip side, the one closer to the house I'm moving into once it's finished, ugh, that one has some of the worst Coke.  Thanks for the tip, I live in the Great Pacific Northwest, recently moved from Oregon to Washington & thank goodness there's still Fred Meyer stores to where I moved to, just less than where I use to live. I'll have to swing by there & pick up some of their in store brand soda. I just don't drink diet so I think I'll go for the regular which like, I think I had as a kid because Fred Meyer use to have a soda machine with a off brand soda, I could never remember what brand it was but it was in the in between area of the entrance & it was like 75 cents a bottle I think so as a kid going there & my dad being cheap & not buying any Coke, I'd make sure to bring a dollar with me & getting a soda from the machine when I went. It wasn't Coke but it was still good.  Where I grew up, not sure about where I live now, there was a mix of ways to say soda. Soda was probably the most common people would say but I heard pop every once in a while & my dad says cola. I grew the habit of saying cola due to him but never when I order because you go to a Pepsi restaurant & you want to order a drink with a self serve fountain so you ask for the generic soda cup, you ask for a medium cola, 9 times out of 10 the worker will say, "we have Pepsi here." They think you mean Coca-Cola because Pepsi Cola isn't as commonly said I suppose? I try telling my dad to not say cola, especially that it doesn't count for all sodas but he still says cola. I hate that I picked that up from him. It's like "dad, you want a diet orange Sunkist, that's not a cola." He'd argue that all sodas are cola. Maybe it's a central/eastern Washington thing since that's where he grew up? I don't know. I prefer saying soda myself because everyone gets what you mean. Oh, I know people who would get on your case if you said "soda pop" so I guess it's best to not say that if you're ever in Portland Oregon.

B: Soda. I'm from Texas, and while to SOME degree it's true that 'Coke' can refer to any soda/pop in the South, I'm under the impression that's becoming outdated, if it's not already. Anytime I have ordered a Coke anywhere within the last ten years or so, I have not then been asked "what kind?" and I just get a Coke. To my experience, it is understood that a Coke is a Coke and not any other soda/pop. I'm not completely if it's just the area I'm in, my age group, or the blanket term no longer being a blanket term, but I'm willing to bet it's the latter.

The ending made me cry.  There're no Krogers in my area and they're my ABSOLUTE favorite diet root beer.  (Been wanting to make a 2 hour trip just to get a bunch of diet root beer.)  That said, here's another option for Mr and Mrs Pat:  Set up a kegerator, but fill it with water.  50 lbs co2 pressure for carbonation and 10-15lbs for maintainence.  You'll be able to make your own soda that way.  Fun to experiment with odd flavors and cheaper in the long run.  I usually make mine by either kool-aid packets, singles to go, or best of all Torani syrups and their competitors.  Some of the off brands I find at Tuesday morning have some really weird flavors so I currently have the options of cookie dough, cinnamon, candied apple, and mint chocolate.  The absolute best, though was a butter rum they had around Christmas. Side note:  I'm diabetic, so stuck with diet sodas and there's not always much option for me, especially since I hate both diet coke and diet pepsi.  I'm also burnt out on diet Dr Pepper.  If a place doesn't have coke zero or a freestyle machine, I end up drinking water or.... restaurant version of my home soda game, I carry a squeeze bottle flavor enhancer (mio, etc) and just order club soda when eating out so I can make my own sodas there too.
I used to enjoy Diet Coke for as long as I can go for, but I'm mostly going for Coke Zero over it. So, I'm with Stephanie's side of the final decision. Coke Zero for life.

From the UK - I call it Fizzy
As someone else who consumes entirely too much Diet Coke, I drank Sam's as a replacement for a few years but the flavor and carbonation were inconsistent between batches. I'd be willing to try a different store brand (especially since I've had a few bad batches of Diet Coke lately, but that might be due to temporary bottling plant sourcing/changes), but I'm not confident I wouldn't run into the same issue. For some reason, citrus-based sodas (lemon/lime, grapefruit, orange) seem to be more consistent.
Because the big chains tend to overload the sugar in their products, I find myself oftentimes preferring the lesser syrup added for cost savings in the store brands. It actually has a better balance to the oversweetened national brands.   Just my thoughts.

Of course these are your local bottled sodas, including the Coke branded ones... while the syrup for a particular brand is usually the same everywhere there are regional variations due to the water the bottling plants use.  In theory its all filtered using similar equipment and the same everywhere but there are always variations in water quality.  There are likely subtle but noticeable differences between Florida bottled Coke and New York bottled Coke.  https://www.coca-colacompany.com/news/bottling-operations-return-to-local-partners

RE: aspartame  just because a lot of countries ban something, doesn't necessarily mean it is bad for you. i don't know whether it is or not myself. but just going off how many countries ban something as an indicator of healthiness is **really** unscientific.  and if it is only two "experts" calling for the ban, out of how many thousands of food safety experts that exist in the world, i would call that suspicious.  i am open to the idea that aspartame is actually bad for you, but i would want to see evidence from long term scientific studies on the topic, not just hear from two fringe experts.  as a sort of science communicator brand, i would expect you to do better.

As someone that worked at a food production facility... changing labels without altering the recipes used is a no go at least where i used to work ... each label has its own recipe... they can be very close (aka 1 or 2 grams of more sugar or citric acid for instance) but never the same per label.
When I worked for Sanderson Farms years back we packaged the same chicken for local brands. The chicken came from literally the same place. Absolutely nothing was different aside from the packaging.

my prediction for winner: coke zero
I had Coca Cola Life once, and honestly I wish they'd replace all the other diet Coca Cola with it, because it tasted like normal cola. I don't like 90% of diet sodas. They just taste bad, and I feel like I'm gonna get diabetes from drinking it. But Cola Life tasted good.   I also have a personal tier list of best "source/container" for soda  1.Glass bottle. It gives a much cleaner taste, and there isn't an issue with overcarbonation. And it just looks better. Problem is most need a bottle opener, and it's less convinient to recycle where I live.  2. Plastic bottle. It isn't as pure as glass, but it still tastes great, and there's more variation in the size of the bottle. It's also re-sealable, so you don't have to drink all of it before the carbonation disappears. It's also more convenient to recycle than glass. You put it into a machine at your local grocery store that collects bottles and cans, the machine scans a code on the bottle or can, then you get a receipt you can cash in at the store.  3. Can. It depends, and honestly it could be next to plastic bottles. But sometimes there's a slight metallic taste, especially to Coca Cola's ones for some reason. They are also recyclable in that you can put them in the same machine as the plastic bottles.  4. Fountain. Honestly, I don't like them. They don't taste right, which is because of how it mixes the beverage, and the fact it relies upon the ice melting and thinning it out. And I most often don't get ice for my beverage, because I don't need it, and a cup of ice is obnoxiously loud.  But if there is one soda I truly wish I could drink again, it would be Grape Soda. A soda made with grapefruit, and part of my childhood  "The world has ever tasted" Meanwhile just showing a map of the US, as if the rest of the planet doesn't exist.  And Lastly, Diet soda isn't actuallty healthier than normal soda. Sugar has been under a lot of critizism, a lot of which is unjustified. But when it comes to soda, while diet may not use sweeteners like sugar, they are loaded with artificial sweeteners which the body may not even be able to break down. This isn't such an issue for diabetics, which diet soda was initially advertised for, but flooding a healthy body with sweetners the body can't break down can cause issues with your insulin levels, and can in some studies increase the likelyhood of developing diabetes. And even if we look past the sweet debate, a lot of sodas are fully of other things that aren't exactly part of your daily intake of vitamins. There's also the psychological aspect to take into account. Since regular soda is known to be unhealthy, you're potentially less likely to drink excessive amounts of it. However, diet soda is often advertised as the "healthier" option, and companies spends a lot of moneyt advertising their diet sodas by making is seem cool, hip, and good to drink diet. But in truth, diet is seen by many experts just as bad as regular soda. If you want to drink a true "diet soda", then what you need is just a glass of soda water, or carbonated water. Throw in some lemon juice or something if you want. But that is the ultimate "diet soda". It's just fancy water with bite

As a fan of bitter and sour flavours; it doesnt surprise me at all that citric acid keeps bein key to so many foods. You need that balancing sour note to rly help make the overall experience more enjoyable, esp with highly sugar or highly fatty foods; bcuz without some bitter or sour notes it will be overpoweringly sweet or fatty. Which is sometimes enjoyable, but in sips not in glugs, heh. (See that cough syruppy soda for what i mean)  My drink of choice is actually just slightly lemon or lime or other sour flavoured water (ideally seltzer water bcuz bubbly is better) and I mean very slightly flavoured. It doesnt even rly need sugar/sweetener in it for me but if it has sugar i can flavour the water more and not risk havin an extra bitter drink cuz of that heh. I dont like most fake sugars tho as theyre overpoweringly sweet alrdy and even moreso to me as a person who almost nvr invests highly sweet stuff except if its frozen (cold makes flavours more bearable; same reason beer and alcohol ads always encourage drinking the coldest of drinks).  Funny thing is I can totes guzzle a coke or any offbrand coke (except pepsi, or similarly extra sweet colas) bcuz they have enuf acids and bubbles to mute the flavours, esp when combined with drinking them ice cold and my havin spent most my life guzzlin them heh. But like, a frosted cake? I cant devour such a thing, bcuz the frosting is cloyingly sweet to me.

Citric acid is so popular because it's super easy to manifacture and it's the go to for weak acid compounds. I mean, I doubt FDA would ever approve a soda with nitric acid...
I'm from upstate NY and I think the most common variant here is soda. That's what I tend to use, at least. Though I've also occasionally heard it said as "soda pop," so I always assumed that was the full version, and that the people here who called it "pop" were just truncating "soda pop" but were also just too much in a rush to say "soda." Another fairly common way of referring to it here is "soft drinks."  So essentially I've heard everything here, and I wasn't ever confused hearing someone from somewhere else calling it something other than "soda." xD The 2 things that really blew my mind when I first learned about the regional differences were 1) the fact that people from the south just call everything "coke," and 2) that the regional variations were *so* strong that some people somehow had no idea that any other variations existed. o.0

For future reference, remember to "wash" your palette's between testing to get a more accurate taste of the flavor. Results might be skewed if one of the drinks linger on your palette when you drink another.  It's also the reason why certain dishes can taste better in a certain order, or vice versa. Like, if you eat a super rich and flavorful soup and then try eating another dish, the dish might taste bland because your tongue is still affected by the previous dish.

I've lived in Texas all my life and call it soda... Using Coke to universally refer to all soft drinks is stupid.
While it's good to not want to drink your calories, that really is the least of your worries when drinking brown sodas. Also, your testing method is flawed. Studies have shown that the human brain, when told two things should be different, will find/create differences that dont actually exist (specifically the experiment of having a room full of people judge the quality of something, then being brought the exact same item again and being told it's a similar brand. The people found difference that couldn't possibly exist.) The flaw here is the question being asked, there's an unproven assumption that soda in different forms (ie can vs bottle vs fountain vs brand vs diet vs generic, etc...) WILL be different from each other. No control testing for this was done before having the competition.

As someone who drinks Diet Coke almost as much as you do, when you mentioned the "Different Taste" thing at 4:05, I was nodding my head along. I'm from the UK and we call them Fizzy Drinks (more colloquially) or Soft Drinks (on menus) but honestly we call Cola flavours Coke, lemon/lime flavours Lemonade, and everything else mostly by the brand. Also we also often add '-ade' to the end of fruits a lot for, like, generic brands of fizzy fruit drinks. (Cherry-ade, Lemon-ade, Orange-ade etc.)

I have a hypothesis as for why the fountain soda was sweeter: because of the concentration of syrup and flavoring agent. Iâ€™m probably wrong, but with fountain needing resupplies of flavoring agent, while in factories the syrup amount can be more uniform, if the fountain has a fresh supply of syrup, it gives it more of a cola taste.

Me as soon as I saw that title: ð˜•ð˜°ð˜±ð˜¦... ð˜•ð˜° ð˜ºð˜°ð˜¶ ð˜¢ð˜ªð˜¯'ð˜µ
A bothersome thing I've noticed in a lot of your taste and smell comparison videos on this channel is that you don't pallet cleanse between samples. The human brain tends to "lock on" to certain flavors, weakening their expression, when consumed regularly. If you force your taste buds or nose to taste or smell something radically different between samples, you'll achieve a much more accurate understanding of the items being compared.  You should have kept a large glass of cold, very bitter coffee next to your sample there. You wouldn't have to drink much, just swish and spit, and allow the smell to waft into your nose to force your brain to sense "bitter" over anything "sweet" between samples, or else prior samples might taint the flavor of the next sample in line.

When you like the fruity flavour, try Mezzo Mix, SchwipSchwap or one of the other versions (these are from Coca Cola and Pepsi) that are a mixture between Cola and Fanta (or what ever other companies call them). It is something as far as I know limited to Germany, Austria and Switzerland, but here you won't find a restaurant etc that doesn't have either Mezzo Mix etc as bottle, can etc or simply Spezi (short for Spezial [special], originating from the German brewery Paulaner) on the menu. It is honestly something that I miss when I'm on vacation. I think, I also never saw Mezzo Mix in Italian Switzerland, so it may be just a good drink known by practically all Germans that other cultures just don't know about

fun fact Del haze Americas(Food lions parent company) is Diet Pepsi. As Pepsi franchises their production and sells the extra to store chains at a discount. most store brands are extra bought from name brands with exceptions for things like whole foods. the most common name brands to sell their extras are RC cola and Pepsi. I learned this working at Hannaford(another del haze chain) while talking to some of our distributors and  drivers.

Fountain shouldn't even be a choice option.  Every single fountain uses a different concentration of syrup to water depending on how cheep the restaurant is. Both Mc Donnalds and that mom and pop short-order place down the street both use soda fountains but you know mom and pop's place puts a better amount of syrup in and makes a taster coke then the big chain stores and their cheep tactics and their extra ice. Can out of the can is better then bottle out of the bottle, but bottle to glass can be better then can to glass if you pour it right. See even pouring the coke makes a difference. And on top of all that, what state or country your coke was bottled or canned in or syrup produced makes a difference. Glass Bottle Cokes from Mexico are the best tasting versions of coke out there. My favourite Cola is actually from Air Up, which I got introduced to thanks to SORTED food. It (ab)uses the fact most of your taste is smell/aroma and manages to flavour water with exactly that, meaning you are just drinking water and smelling Coke. Hi
What makes diet coke unique among diet sodas is it was made to taste good, not to mimic regular coke. Rather than being a poor man's substitute of the original like most diet sodas or coke zero, it didn't try to taste the same. It's its own unique flavor that people like so much that allegedly New Coke from the 80s was just diet Coke with sugar.

When I first found out about this channel, I was elated as a nutrition-interest young lad - a charismatic dude like Matpat making content about food, what else could I wish for? Therefore I am a little disappointed to find out that it's really not about nutrition at all. I was moreso expecting a deeper dive into perhaps the lesser known facts about nutrition that may currently be controversial within mainstream media or even the scientific community. But I guess it's again entertainment > education, though I personally think that more in-depth content about more practical and controversial food+health related topics would be just as, if not more entertaining.

Like some restaurants have disgusting water so the soda also tastes gross itâ€™s a gamble with restaurants and the soda. The bottle and can donâ€™t taste the same either. In all these places itâ€™s a different experience. To me canned Diet Coke is more crisp and refreshing while bottle is more subtle and well put together; I think this is because can soda is really a one and done situation. With canned soda you donâ€™t want to save it cause it just ruins the experience and nobody really likes leaving open cans outside, I have fears that bugs will enter the drink.
